tei:p.tei:hi: Handwritten letter from Schenker to Cotta, dated July 2, 1906

tei:transcription.tei:p: [not in Schenker’s hand:] Schenker, H. [in Schenker’s hand:] Wien, 2. Juli 1906

Da der Beisp. 173 nicht zum Haupttext, sondern zur Fußnote gehört, so ist es notwendig, dies auch äußerlich kenntlich zu machen. Ex. 173 quotes the Max Reger Piano Quintet, Op.64 in score, and belongs to footnote 1, beginning on p.220 and continuing through to p.226. (The footnote is entirely omitted from the Mann Borghese trans., the corresponding place in which is p.174, line 9 at the phrase “step progression.”) The footnote is a controversial one in which Schenker, having in the main text remarked that modern music is at fault in lacking the scale-degree, begins: “As a deterrent example, I give here the opening of the Quintet Op. 64 of a modern composer ...”, describes the passage as “one big, totally irrational mass” and the composer as “devoid of all musical instinct”, and ends by decrying Reger’s being hailed by critics as a “master of musical composition.” See CA 1-2, November 8, 1905, paragraph 4, for reference to Reger in his initial proposal to Cotta. Ich bitte daher, den Herrn Setzer aufmerksam zu machen, daß dieses Arrangement sehr leicht durchzuführen ist, indem die letzten 3 Zeilen des Haupttextes S. 220 auf die <strike>S</strike> nächste Seite 221 transportiert, The proof must have had five lines of main text on p.220, since it now has two before the footnote begins. u. vom Haupttext des S. 224 ja ein paar Zeilen <strike>für</strike> an S. 222 u. 223 abgegeben werden, während die Anmerkung unter dem Strich fortläuft. Line: the short horizontal rule separating the main text from the footnote on all seven pages. The footnote text continues through to p.224, the example to p.226.
Mit bestem Dank Ihr ergeb. [signed:] H Schenker

tei:p.tei:hi: Handwritten letter from Schenker to Cotta, dated July 2, 1906

tei:translation.tei:p: [not in Schenker’s hand:] Schenker, H. [in Schenker’s hand:] Vienna, July 2, 1906

Since music example 173 belongs not to the main text but to the footnote, it is necessary to make this crystal clear. I should like therefore to draw the type-setter’s attention to the fact that this arrangement can be effected very easily by moving the last three lines of main text from p. 220 to the following page, 221, and shifting a few lines from the main text of p.224 back to pp. 222 and 223, and letting the footnote flow on continuously beneath the line.
With many thanks, Yours truly, [signed:] H Schenker
